passages.text: Must- Reads and Highlights from Equity Research

Nothing beats a Jet2- holiday JPM September Issue. Our sector teams highlight their key views and upcoming catalysts in H2, and recap their content highlights in case you missed them (summary on page 5- 6). We hope this will help you to both catch up post the summer and look forward to what we anticipate will be in focus in the remainder of H2.

Mark your calendars: We have \(>125\) EMEA access events through September and October, including C- Suite meetings, global Conferences, company Roadshows and Expert calls. These events are flagged on each sector page, alongside a summary of upcoming CMDs by sector group on page 7.
This month in J.P. Morgan Europe Equity Research...

- Getting amped up. Philip Buller launched on new top pick Siemens (OW, AFL), placing the shares on +CW into the December CMD, with Legrand (OW, AFL) his preferred name to play the multi-year Electricals trade.
- Pay(ments)-to-play. Sandeep Deshpande reiterated his OW on Adyen. Craig McDowell set out the fundamental case for Wise (OW) ahead of its US listing.
- Refining investment cases. Matthew Lofting upgraded Repsol to OW and cut Equinor to UW, as diesel-led refining hedges against a strengthening oil price.
- Dialled in on Telcos. Akhil Dattani upgraded Bouygues to OW on boosted margin assumptions, and updated Orange (OW, AFL) consolidation analysis.

- Testing the theses. Anchal Verma initiated on two In-Vitro Diagnostics names, anticipating risk to top-line growth and limited margin expansion for Diasorin (UW), with more balanced risk-reward for bioMérieux (N).

- All roads lead to higher European Defence spending. David Perry maintained his conviction in the upward trajectory for EU Defence spend, and saw an entry point in Rheinmetall (OW) as shares pulled back on geopolitical news flow and the momentum shift away from the sector.

- Data points of interest. Richard Vosser upgraded Sanofi to OW expecting de-risking from COAST-1 trial data, while a weak data report from peer Eli Lilly on its oral GEP-1 drug reduced competitive pressure on Novo Nordisk (OW).
- Anchoring the debates. Alexia Dogani refreshed her outlook on Container Shippin industry dynamics, and reiterated her bearish view of Maersk (UW).
- What's trending? Highest volume of interactions and highest increases MOM: ATG (L Simpson), CCH (P Spain), Maersk (A Dogani).
- First Principles on IMI, In-Vitro Diagnostics.
- Conviction into events: 6 stocks placed on Catalyst Watch.
- Derivatives expressions: Europe outperformance, Rheinmetall & Engie.

- Upcoming Conferences: U.S. All Stars (Sep 16-17), Global Beauty (Sep 18), Global Tech Stars (Oct 7-8), Global Energy (Nov 3-4), Global Luxury and Brands (Nov 12-13), UK Leaders (Nov 18-19), EU Financials (Nov 20-21).
Head of EMEA Equity Research
Head of EMEA Equity Research Content

Table of Contents Upgrades / Downgrades In 60 seconds Catalyst Watch Month in Charts JPM Earnings estimate changes vs. share price performance Forward Focus Analyst Focus List Valuation Multiples & Growth Forecast First Principles Upcoming EMEA Access Replays Meet the Teams

A lot happens in a month - EU Insights is the monthly publication that allows our clients to stay updated on the most important content and events from EMEA Equity Research and on what's next, in one pass.
See page 100 for analyst certification and important disclosures, including non- US analyst disclosures.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

SectorKey CallsSector viewAerospace &amp; DefenceDavid PerryOW: Babcock, Hensoldt, RENK, Rheinmetall, Rolls RoyceWe remain very positive on the outlook for both European Civil Aero (ECA) and the European Defence Sector (EDS). ECA should enjoy many years of good growth (OE and aftermarket) even as it grapples with supply chain issues, though we recognise a weaker US$ would be a headwind. We see the pullback in the EDS as a compelling entry point as we expect strong multi-year growth in European defence spending due to: the need to rebuild capability after the c30 year peace dividend; the threat from Russia; and the fact that the US is no longer willing to pay for Europe's defence. July's US-EU trade deal imposed a 15% import tariff on most EU goods, including automotive. We view this as a manageable y/y increase (12.5%), which can be mitigated by: a) increased product localization in the US, b) low-single-digit price hikes, and c) the possibility for company-level exemptions. We are cautiously optimistic for 2H as our major concerns—high tariffs, recession risks, CO2 targets in Europe, and Chinese OEMs gaining share—are now more manageable or less significant, though Chinese OEMs will eventually accelerate as they localize production in Europe. We expect performance to stay mixed given uneven end-market demand across sub-sectors. Structural growth areas like energy transition services, U.S. non-residential construction, and credit data digitalization should remain resilient, while names exposed to cyclical markets such as RS Group (N) and the staffers are likely to remain volatile. That said, we see limited risk to 2H expectations given prudent management commentary and undemanding guidance. In addition, we see potential for M&A to re-emerge as a theme with an increasingly supportive interest rate environment. For Logistics, we expect slowing demand trends into 2H given US tariffs and the proposed suspension of all de-minimis exemption rules for RoW to US shipments from 29-Aug, impacting ocean freight, air freight and Express. In container shipping, we expect supply to continue outgrowing demand, tipping the industry back to EBIT losses from 4Q. For Airlines, we are constructive as fuel prices remain relatively low, supply growth looks manageable, and we see opportunities for pricing growth at Ryanair (OW) on weak comps and IAG (OW) given abetter UK/Spain.Business ServicesKarin SoUW: AdeccoTransport &amp; LogisticsAlexia Dogani, HarryGowersOW: DSV (AFL), IAG (AFL, +CW)MaterialsThe key debates into H2 centre on whether the 'green shoots' in Europe that companies have been referring to translate into improved volumes and earnings, and on whether the US remains in 'wait and see' mode. If uncertainty does recede in the US the pent-up demand from H1 could prove supportive of volumes. By subsector, we continue to prefer the Heavyside to the Lightside given structural tailwinds for the former from decarbonisation and a likely pricing premium for green cement products, while the absence of a volume recovery in Europe persists for the Lightside. We prefer toll roads/contractors to airports at present, noting the tailwind to contracting activities from Germany's infrastructure plan and the historically greater resilience of toll road traffic in periods of economic downturn or uncertainty. We also note the strategic uncertainty facing ADP (OW) and Aena (N), both of which will submit proposals for their next regulatory periods in the coming months and face directionally higher capex requirements. The UK Housebuilders have underperformed YTD, down 4%, reflecting uncertainty over the UK Government's ability to meet its target of building 1.5m new homes as well as weaker house price data in recent months. In our view, with the sector's P/ TNAV of 0.9x near 2022 lows, this has now been fully understood by the market. We see reasons for momentum to improve, noting that it takes time for the impact of the planning changes implemented since Jul-24 to be seen in starts and completions, and increases in funding for the Affordable Homes Programme announced in June. The sector is beset by more structural issues - industry oversupply and rising competition from Chinese/Asian peers - than cyclical demand issues, meaning our conviction on the timing and magnitude of any material earnings improvement in the near-term is low. While the anti-involution theme could be a game changer, we think the more likely outcome is a slowdown in future capacity expansions, the benefit of which wouldn't be seen for years. Our bottom-up supply-demand analysis indicates that a proper market healing is unlikely until 2028 across most commodity chains.Building MaterialsElodie RallOW: Heidelberg (AFL), Saint-GobainInfrastructureElodie RallOW: Eiffage, VinciUK HousebuildersZaim BeekawaOW: Bellway, PersimmonChemicalsChetan UdeshiOW: IIMCD (AFL), Syensco (AFL) UW: BASF, DSM-FirmenichMetals, Mining &amp; SteelDominic O'KaneOW: Antofagasta (AFL), GlencoreUW: BolidenPaper &amp; PackagingDetlef WinckelmannOW: Smurfit WestRock (AFL), UPMTMTFor the semiconductor companies, we have likely passed trough revenue and earnings with Q2 results. Going forward, the set up—with still high consensus expectations for 2026 and elevated inventory across the value chain—leaves us cautious on the pace and trajectory of a recovery on both revenues and margins. The picture is brighter for the semiannual, with the announced US tariff exemption on semiannual equipment likely to support order intake for the balance of the year. All merchant servicing companies in our coverage noted a deceleration in volume growth in Q2, albeit with companies pointing to idiosyncratic reasons. We expect that the macroeconomic will become more of a feature in H2, where consensus and management are largely expecting a benign backdrop. The incumbent players continue to face questions around competition and market share loss, although we see Nexi as adapting better to a lower growth future. Wise, as a cross-border payment provider, should be more insulated. We continue to see secular drivers in the Software market as organisations demand more mechanisms for further automation. Nearer term, we think the debate regarding AI disruption and monetisation could lead to some level of volatility in valuations until a stronger consensus is formed. SAP (OW, AFL) continues to be our highest conviction call on idiosyncratic factors (migration cycle, AI beneficiary and restructuring). Nemetschek (UW) remains our least preferred name on slowing growth alongside a stretched relative valuation. AI, macro &amp; M&A are likely to remain key themes. Stock picking will remain key. Our highest conviction OWs are UMG &amp; RELX, while unloved and underwound European broadcasters could continue to outperform. While Classifieds remain firmly in focus, we argue for a bottom-up selection process to pick the winners in the space. We prefer, in particular, those names with self-help potential in the form of cost savings and tipping point profitability that drives EBITDA growth over the next few years. Further, potential M&A scenarios in Europe and increasing speculation on asset availability in 2026 are now defining industry trends, with the sector likely to see further takeouts in the areas of Online Classifieds and Food Delivery in H2 and beyond. We expect event driven catalysts to remain the key determinant of relative share price performances over H2. (1) Regulation: Green shoots of change are already being evidenced by localised deregulation, the Draghi report, several 4-to-3 mobile merger approvals with benign remedies, the new Competition Commissioner reviewing merger rules, and the EU sovereignty agenda gaining importance, (2) Consolidation: We believe French consolidation could materialise in H2. Mid-term, we also expect mergers across Germany, the UK, Sweden, Denmark and Italy.Tech HardwareSandeep DeshpandeOW: ASML, NokiaPaymentsSandeep Deshpande, Craig McDowellOW: Adyen, WiseSoftware &amp; ITServicesToby OggOW: SAP (AFL) UW: NemetschekMediaDaniel KervenOW: RELX (AFL), UMG (AFL)InternetMarcus DiebelOW: Auto1, Ocado, Scout24 (AFL)TelecomsAkhil DattaniOW: BT (AFL), Orange (AFL), Tele2
Source: J.P. Morgan.

Sector ConsumerKey CallsSector viewConsumer Staples, Beverages &amp; TobaccoCeline PannutiOW: ABI, Beiersdorf, Danone, Heineken, Kerry Group, UnileverThe sector derated further following H1 reporting despite broadly unchanged earnings, opening up compelling opportunities at a time of heightened cyclical vs defensive positioning. FY25e earnings were adjusted (vs pre-Q2) up for Spirits and Food, vs. lower for Beer, HPC and Ingredients. Overall, we are 1% below cons. EPS 25/26e, with notable exceptions including Nestle (N) and Henkel (OW), where JPME is 3%/2% ahead, ABI (OW) and Heineken (OW), where JPME is 5%/3% ahead, and Remy Cointreau (UW), where JPME is -11% below.Luxury &amp; Sporting GoodsChiara BattistiniOW: On, Prada, RichemontUW: Kering, SwatchWe note that Luxury comps ease in Q3 but are tough in Q4, leaving us with a still difficult backdrop into year-end and a sector still likely in reset mode. In this context, and with uncertainty over next year's growth outlook, still struggle to see a catalyst to drive a sector re-rating. In contrast, we remain more positive on Sporting Goods, mainly on (OW) and adidas (OW), with strong current trading and solid order books despite a volatile environment, while we are more cautious on Puma (N).General RetailGeorgina JohananOW: Marks &amp; SpencerUW: KingfisherInto H2, UK macro is a concern and we are mindful of a tough Sep comp across all markets. Below top line, external factors have been helpful and we continue to expect FX and freight tailwinds into cal-2026. Increasingly, the debate has centered around whether retailers will reinvest tailwinds into price. The exception to the tailwinds is US tariffs - within our coverage the key loser is H&M (UW), where we estimate a &lt; 10% hit to group EBIT before any mitigations. Primark (ABF, N) could also experience an annualised margin impact of c.40bps pre-mitigations.Food RetailBorja OlceseOW: Jeronimo Martins (AFL), Sainsbury, TescoUW: Ahold-Delhaize, B&amp;M, CarrefourWe see the food retail sector as stock-picker territory. Jeronimo Martins is our top pick, followed by UK grocers Sainsbury &amp; Tesco (all three OW). We identify earnings/FCF/ capital return reset risks at B&amp;M, Carrefour and Ahold-Delhaize (all UW).Leisure, Hotels &amp; GamingEstelle WeingrodOW: Compass, FlutterUW: IHG1) Gaming: Our preferred sub-sector. We favour market leading operators with superior product/tech, with Flutter our highest conviction OW. 2) Hotels: We are more selective, preferring Accor and TUI (both OW) to IHG (UW). 3) Catering: We focus on execution and contract with momentum, favouring Compass (OW). 4) Vouchers: We prefer Edenred (OW) to Pluxee (N) due to a superior track record and more diversified business model. 5) UK Pubs: Our preference remains for Marston's (OW) given ongoing margin expansion and de-leveraging.EnergyLow global oil inventories signal a tight prompt market but geopolitical risks remain two-way and rate of change will move into focus as OPEC+ inclusive supply surpluses build. In contrast, we believe EU diesel is poised to exhibit sustained tightness, with diesel-led refining thus offering a strengthened oil price hedge. In EU Oils, a 2026e FCF yield 8.2% at $65/bbl is broadly in line with the LT average. With that backdrop, we prefer names we believe offer superior barges of leverage and resilience: OW Shell, Eni, TotalEnergies and Repsol (for diesel), vs. UW Equinor and OMV.Oil &amp; GasMatthew LoftingOW: Eni, Repsol, Shell (AFL)UW: EquinorWe stay tactically cautious into the autumn due to likely speculation on higher taxes in selected countries (France, Italy) around discussions on 2026 Budgets and in a context where a potential peace deal in the Ukrainian war could bring additional downside pressure to gas (and hence power) prices. We remain positive longer term as we continue to believe in a medium term growth outlook for power demand that should provide support to power prices and to returns on new capex.Utilities &amp; Clean EnergyJavier GarridoOW: RWE, SSE (AFL)We remain constructive on the sector, trading at 8.9x PE, 1.3x PNAV for 15.5% RoTE in 2027E, implying a CoE of c11% which we believe should decline to 10% over time given: 1) more visibility on the earnings outlook with preprovision profit growth of 5% CAGR 25-27E for the sector; 2) stronger balance sheets vs. history with asset quality risks concentrated in specific pockets and the ability to absorb 250+bps of loan loss provisions; 3) stronger capital generation with CET1 of 14.3% 25/26E, offering sustainable returns of 15-16% ROTE, and an attractive total yield of 9% 25E. We also see tariffs as less of an earnings risk compared to other sectors, although our focus has been on the impact on rates which has been limited so far. Our top picks are Barclays, Deutsche Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, UBS, Société Générale and NatWest (all OW).FinancialsWe expect the Private markets managers to perform well in H2, on the back of improving exit volumes and strong fundraising. Within traditional asset managers we expect higher margin active flows to remain challenged, and we expect to see continued strength in passive funds, which favors OW (OW). We expect strong net flows to persist for asset gatherers, with Italian wealth managers well positioned given attractive valuations and structural growth trends. Lastly, we could see some catch-up on LSEG (OW, AFL) following an under-served underperformance YTD.BanksKian AbouhosseinOW: Barclays, Société Générale, UBS (AFL)While sector valuations look high relative to history, we remain constructive. The sector offers attractive capital return, supported by strong capitalisation, with a &lt; 5% 2026E dividend yield (1.4x market) and an additional &lt; 1% yield from buybacks. The sector has experienced earnings upgrades over 1 and 3-years (well ahead of the market) and has been defensive during recent macro uncertainty, supported by top-line growth in life and P&amp;C and strong investment margins. Our forecasts are ahead of consensus (2026E) for &lt; 2/3rds of our coverage.Diversified FinancialsAngeliki Bairaktari, Enrico BolzoniOW: CVC, ICG, LSEG (AFL)Looking ahead, we see the listed sector poised to rebound from deeply discounted levels, should the top-down turn more benign, allowing for a further recovery in transaction activity and a re-engagement with fundamentals, which remain broadly robust across the sector. Risks remain, with political events such as the UK Budget and the recently announced confidence vote in France of particular note into H2.InsuranceFarooq HanifOW: Beazley, Generali, Munich ReUW: ZurichWe expect updates on US Section 232 tariffs in the coming weeks, where we see a broadly manageable impact for EU Pharma, in part due to the significant US investments announced and the announced 15% cap on the EU. On MFN drug pricing, where an update is anticipated by September 29, we see the potential pathway to implementation as challenging.PropertyNeil GreenOW: Great PortlandEstates, SEGRO (AFL)We see relatively limited opportunities as uncertainties persist and the sector has rebounded since April (Liberation Day). Pockets of opportunity may appear as 8 of our companies host CMDs in H2 and as the market starts to look into FY26, though this will largely depend on Management teams' ability to manage expectations during Q3 reporting.HealthcareWe are incrementally more bullish on the H2 outlook for much of our European coverage, reflecting clear signs of sequential acceleration in European PMIs and resistance (albeit from low levels), and a better-than-expected Q2 reporting season. Acceleration remains the key area of strength, with strong demand across the electricity value chain, and short-cycle appears to have bottomed with indications it is turning a corner. While other verticals offer a more mixed picture, we see signs of sequential improvement across the board as we look ahead into the catalyst rich H2 and 2026.Pharma &amp; BiotechRichard VisserOW: AstraZeneca, Novo Nordisk, SanofiMedical Technology &amp; ServicesDavid AdingtonOW: Fresenius SE (AFL), Smith &amp; Nephew (+CW)UW: Carl Zeiss, DiasorinWe see relatively limited opportunities as uncertainties persist and the sector has rebounded since April (Liberation Day). Pockets of opportunity may appear as 8 of our companies host CMDs in H2 and as the market starts to look into FY26, though this will largely depend on Management teams' ability to manage expectations during Q3 reporting.IndustrialsWe are incrementally more bullish on the H2 outlook for much of our European coverage, reflecting clear signs of sequential acceleration in European PMIs and resistance (albeit from low levels), and a better-than-expected Q2 reporting season. Acceleration remains the key area of strength, with strong demand across the electricity value chain, and short-cycle appears to have bottomed with indications it is turning a corner. While other verticals offer a more mixed picture, we see signs of sequential improvement across the board as we look ahead into the catalyst rich H2 and 2026.Capital GoodsPhil BullerOW: IMI, Metso, Siemens (AFL), Vestas

Global Beauty Conference London, 18 September

- Sector view: The sector derated further following H1 reporting; despite the challenging consumer backdrop, this has opened up compelling opportunities at a time of heightened cyclical vs defensive positioning and downward pressure on bond yields. FY25e earnings were revised (vs pre-Q2) up for Spirits (+2%) and Food (+1%), and lower for Beer (-2%), HPC (-1%), and Ingredients (-1%). Overall, we are 1% below consensus EPS 25/26e - except Nestle (N) and Henkel (OW), where JPMe is 3%/2% ahead, offset by below consensus estimates in Beauty. In Beverages, JPMe is 5%/3% ahead of consensus on ABI (OW) and Heineken (OW), while -4%/-11% below on Pernod-Ricard (N) and Remy Cointreau (UW).

- Beverages - ABI (OW): Post a strong H1 delivery (apart from volumes) ABI is well set to deliver on FY guidance, and offering the best balance of earnings growth, valuation and cash returns. Upcoming catalysts include SBB announcement in Q3 and evidence of sequential volume recovery. Heineken (OW): We expect improved volumes in H2 and solid margin delivery to meet the FY25 guide for +4-8% org. EBIT growth. We expect the valuation discount to close as confidence grows in the FY25 delivery and as ahead of the upcoming CMD in Oct.

- Food/Ingredients - Danone (OW): We see a valuation premium as warranted given the quality of delivery and turnaround that should increasingly be evidenced in EPS compounding going forward. Kerry Group (OW): The stock has continued to de-rate, which we see as compelling for mid-teens TSR potential mid-term, though a volumes acceleration is needed to catalyze a re-rating.

- HPC - Beiersdorf (OW): Amid a slower global beauty market growth at \(\sim 3\%\) in 2025e, the major disappointment in H1 was slower growth in WE and at Nivea fuelling worries about the brand price positioning. As Innovation led launches kick in, we expect an acceleration in Q3 and Q4 to support delivery. Unilever (OW): H125 results reassured on the shape of FY25 delivery but also evidenced improvements in innovation, brand support and execution step up which should underpin MSD MT organic sales and are not yet reflected in valuation.

- Company Capital Markets Day: The Magnum Ice Cream Company (9 Sep), Carlsberg (1 Oct), Heineken (23-24 Oct), L'Oreal (1-3 Dec) and Reckitt (04 Dec).- US NielsenIQ Data: 16 September, 14 October, 11 November, and 9 December.- W.Europe NielsenIQ Data: 5 Sep, 3 Oct, 31 Oct, 28 Nov, and 26 Dec (tbc).- Monthly China Retail Sales Data: 15 Sep, 20 Oct, 14 Nov, and 15 Dec.

The H1 reporting season has been one of the most punitive in European staples that we can recall. While sector earnings were broadly unchanged, the sector de- rated further, now trading at 10- year lows at 18x 12m Fwd PE hit by a combination of weak demand and investors' appetite for cyclicality. We acknowledge the demand environment is unclear amid deceleration in NA and LA, pedestrian China consumption and WE consumers also showing signs of strain, but with several companies warning on sales outlook, H2 expectations look more realistic.

- Sector view: Luxury companies' comments on current trading during Q2 reporting were overall quite lackluster, noting no major changes in trends in July. We note that comps ease in Q3 but are tough in Q4, leaving us with a still difficult backdrop into year-end and a sector still likely in reset mode (no cluster improved in Q2, if anything the Americans and Chinese inc. tourists slowed down sequentially). In this context, and with a growing question mark, in our view, on next year's growth outlook, we still struggle to see a catalyst for the luxury sector as a whole to drive a re-rating. In contrast, we remain more positive on Sporting Goods, mainly On (OW) and adidas (OW), with strong current trading and solid order books despite a volatile environment, while we are more cautious on Puma (N).

- Kering and Swatch (UW): Given still muted top-line momentum and significant operational deleveraging despite ongoing cost saving actions, we continue to see the largest downside risk to numbers at these two names. Kering's turnaround of Gucci should remain a work in progress for the rest of the year, with the new CEO joining in mid-Sept and new designer presenting for the first time for the brand on \(23^{\mathrm{rd}}\) Sept. (with actions from both likely becoming more material from 2026). For Swatch, the watch industry dynamics remain volatile, while FX, raw materials and the new Swiss duties add further headwinds, exacerbating the margin pressures.

- Richemont and Prada (OW): In a currently challenged sector, we think the self-help from solid brand momentum (at Cartier/Van Cleef and Miu Miu) as well as favourable category exposure (jewellery continued to outperform in Q2/H1 25), should help these two names to continue to outperform on a relative basis. For Richemont, specifically, we note that consensus and investor expectations have been adjusting in recent weeks to reflect mounting raw materials headwinds into H2, which we therefore view as priced in at these levels.

- On (OW): The Q2 beat and raise demonstrates the strength of underlying brand momentum and we are encouraged to see strong consumer demand in July and a solid wholesale order book for the upcoming quarters. We view On as one of the few names in the space that continues to deliver despite volatile consumer demand.
- LVMH Q3 25 Sales: Tuesday \(14^{\mathrm{th}}\) October (tbc)- adidas Q3 25 Results: Wednesday \(29^{\mathrm{th}}\) October- Richemont H1 26 Results: Friday \(14^{\mathrm{th}}\) November

The European Luxury Goods sector saw mixed H1 reporting, overall, with broadly soft top lines, but better-than- feared margins. A few things though stood out clearly: the backdrop remains highly volatile, tourists are no longer an easy growth driver, new price hikes are not adding to growth (and value for money brands continue to stand out as seen with Coach, Ralph Lauren, even Kors) and focus on internal execution is becoming increasingly important to navigate a potential new norm. European Sporting Goods fared relatively better in Q2, with robust results at On and adidas; Puma instead posted a weak quarter and is now in a transformation phase under new management.

Marks & Spencer - UK Leaders Conference, London, 18 Nov

Marks & Spencer (OW): Recent conversations have been dominated by cyber attack impacts. However, with click & collect now relaunched in clothing, and the group's highly automated Castle Donington warehouse operational again, we think the balance of risk has shifted to the upside - we expect the focus to start moving back to the fundamental turnaround story. In particular, we continue to see opportunity for share gains in Food, supported by the renewal store programme and other initiatives to capture larger basket shops. While the lack of clothing click & collect weighed on Food footfall, management prioritized availability (over waste) in Food, and we are not concerned about consumer engagement. This is a bigger concern in clothing, where the lack of a full online offer has materially weighed on sales. However, what drew customers back to M&S at the start of the turnaround - improved product style, value and convenience - has not fundamentally changed, and our expectation is that customers should re- engage relatively quickly now that the offer is "back to normal". M&S is trading on a CY 26 (i.e. recovery forecasts) of 11.1x, making it the cheapest stock in our multi- channel coverage.

Kingfisher (UW): While some data points on the UK housing market are improving, there is a lack of consistency, and the UK government reportedly considering changes to the way residential property transactions are taxed adds risk. Combined with a still high savings ratio and concerns on the H2 UK macro outlook, we see the risk to UK forecasts as still being to the downside. In other key regions: the French consumer remains sluggish and DIY sales are still negative (including - \(9\%\) in Jul) despite negative comps; and Poland data also remains somewhat soft in the category. Overall therefore we struggle to become more constructive and see downside amid broader UK concerns.
Earnings: ABF pre- close update (10 Sep), Inditex Q2 25 results (10 Sep), Next H1 26 results (18 Sep), Kingfisher H1 26 results (23 Sep), H&M Q3 25 results (25 Sep)

The European clothing market has been lacklustre in 2025- to- date, and has certainly not (yet at least) witnessed the improvement that we think was hoped for by retailers (we think a better Jul/ Aug is most likely discount driven). In contrast, UK spending on clothing has been robust, albeit supported by weather. However, the UK macro is a concern into H2. For all markets we are mindful of a tough Sep comp. Below top line, external factors have been helpful and we continue to expect FX and freight tailwinds into 2026. Increasingly, the debate has centered around whether retailers will reinvest tailwinds into price. The exception to the tailwinds is US tariffs - within our coverage the key loser is H&M (UW), where we estimate a c. \(10\%\) hit to group EBIT before any mitigations. Primark (ABF (N)) could also experience an annualised margin impact of c.40bps pre- mitigations.

- Sector view: We see the food retail sector as stock-picker territory. Jeronimo Martins is our top pick, followed by UK grocers Sainsbury & Tesco (all three OW). We identify earnings/FCF/capital return reset risks at B&M, Carrefour and Ahold-Delhaize (all UW).

- Jeronimo Martins (OW, AFL): H1 trends suggest Biedronka is back to the virtuous circle, whilst Colombia enjoys strong momentum. To us, earnings offer c10% upside risk and valuation material re-rating potential at c30% discount to history. Like a Swiss watch (link).

- Sainsbury & Tesco (OW): Three key premises drive our bullish stance: (i) rational backdrop, (ii) substantial capital returns, (iii) undemanding expectations (JPMc 5-10% above the St. on EPS). Market share gains continue (link).

- Carrefour (UW): We sit 6-10% below consensus and guidance for EBIT, and are concerned with the recurring low quality of earnings and cash flow, in the context of increasing leverage. On the Defensive (link).

- Ahold-Delhaize (UW): We expect the investment cycle will need to accelerate to cope with WMT/AMZN/discountor inroads. We detail why we are less optimistic than the market in our note The 'Bear' thesis illustrated in 10 figures (link).

- B&M (UW): We forecast that declining sales densities will lead to a holistic re-set. Our Base Case assumes EBITDA margins reset to 9.5% (c50bps below prepandemic levels), sitting at least 5-10% below consensus for profits, FCF and dividends. Kicking the can down the road (link).

- Sector view: Gaming remains our preferred sub-sector, whilst we remain more selective in Hotels, Catering and Vouchers. 1) Gaming: We prefer market leading operators with superior product/tech well-positioned to navigate regulatory headwinds and sports results variability. Our highest conviction OW is Flutter, followed by Lottomatica & OPAP. 2) Hotels: More selective, focusing on equity stories combining a solid RevPAR momentum and near-term positive catalysts. Our preferred stocks are Accor and TUI (both OW) - both more exposed to high-end segments. IHG (UW) remains our least preferred.3) Catering: We focus on execution and contract win momentum - Compass (OW) vs. Sodexo (N). 4) Vouchers: We prefer Edenred (OW) to Pluxee (N) due to its superior track record and more diversified business model. Regulatory concerns remain a material near-term overhang. 5) UK Pubs: Whilst we appreciate the topline defensiveness of UK Pubs overall, our preference remains for Marston's (OW; ongoing margin expansion, de-leveraging) and Young's (OW; best in class with leading profitability, BS).

- Flutter (OW) should continue to benefit from (i) a solid \(+20\%\) organic growth momentum in H2, underpinned by the US (partly helped by easy Q4 sports comps) and (ii) overall defensiveness in case of potential regulatory headwinds (UK/US taxes), given its industry leading moat (scale, brand, product and positioning) and overall geographical diversification.

- Compass (OW): We expect H2 organic growth to remain healthy at \(+8\%\) (broadly stable vs H1), driven by its industry leading net-new business growth of \(+4 - 5\%\) (vs Sodexo close to flat). Separately, with cost inflation remaining at somewhat moderate levels, we see ongoing margin expansion as well underpinned. As a reminder, Compass is the most defensive name in our coverage.

- IHG (UW): With ongoing RevPAR weakness in the US/China (c.70% of sales), relatively challenging RevPAR comps in H2, and a NUG run-rate still behind US peers, we continue to see IHG's valuation as demanding, trading at a c.20% premium to historical multiples (EV/EBITDA). Separately, we continue to see downside risk to estimates (JPME EBIT/EPS c.3% below in FY 26-27).

- Key Events: 1) Young's CMD (Sep 18th), 2) UK Autumn Budget (focus on Gaming Duties), 3) Edenred CMD (Nov 4th), 4) Launch of Italy's new Online concession (Nov 12th), 5) New industry framework for Meal Vouchers in France to be voted (potentially this Autumn)

The summer for European Leisure was in line with the broader market overall i.e., both being broadly flat over the period, with mixed performance across subsectors. Hotels shares averaged \(+7\%\) , underpinned by TUI (+19%; strong Q3, guidance u/g) and Whitbread (+10%; encouraging RevPAR driven by concerts/weather), followed by Catering \(+4\%\) . UK Pubs shares averaged -9% amid uncertainty into the upcoming UK Budget. Gaming shares averaged flat over the same period, with Evolution outperforming (+13%; albeit off a low base) and FDJU lagging (-15%; given H1 miss). Meal Voucher shares averaged +1%.

- Sector view: Low global oil inventories signal a tight prompt market but geopolitical risks remain two-way and rate of change will move into sharper focus from here as OPEC+ inclusive supply surpluses build to YE (JPM Commodities 2.5mb/d oversupply by 4Q; base case Brent falls below \(60 / \mathrm{bb}\) ). In contrast, we believe EU diesel is poised to exhibit sustained tightness as seasonal maintenance and asset closures render a swift recovery in inventories a tall order. This indicates diesel-led refining offers a strengthened oil price hedge through YE. EU Oils valuation screens as fair rather than outright cheap territory; a 2026e FCF yield 8.2% at \(\) 65/bb\(is broadly in line with the LT average and we estimate the shares are pricing in\) \geq \$65/bbL T Brent. With that backdrop our OWs are centred around names we believe offer superior barbells of leverage and resilience. Best ideas: OW Shell, Eni, TotalEnergies and Repsol (for diesel); UW Equinor, OMV.

- Shell (OW, AFL): Superior multi-quarter gearing to O&G volatility (not just price) and accelerating self-help creates an attractive risk/reward on a premium 9.0% 2026e FCF yield. We maintain a UK preference over N-rated BP where 2Q offered a welcome step forward but further proof points are required to signal a sustained inflection capable of reducing its higher macro procyclicity.
- Eni (OW): Leading rate of change in strategic delivery and deleveraging puts a strong floor on a 10.1% '25 cash yield; momentum screens strongly through YE.

- Equinor (UW): At \(\) 65\(Brent, €30 - 35 EU gas Equinor exhibits the sector's greatest re - gearing to end - 26 (+900pp ND/CE, avg 230). UW reflects our concern that the risk this and the portfolio's high leverage to moderated O&G prices presents to 2026 + TSR is insufficiently priced into valuation at a sub - 6% 2026e FCF yield.

- Repsol (OW): The sector's prime beneficiary of sustained diesel market tightness and any OPEC - induced widening in crude price spread. into '26. Repsol's EPS sensitivity per \(\) 1/bb\(refining margin is a top end 7% and a 7.0% div yield suggests plenty of room for a diesel - stimulated re - rating.

- Oil & OPEC+: OPEC - 8 monthly (next: 7 Sept) and OPEC's semi-annual (30 Nov) meetings for next policy steps following the tapering of voluntary quota cuts.- EU gas: The extent storage rebuild remains on - track to meet EU's revised target.- Corporate Investor Days: TotalEnergies annual update 29 September; OMV 6 October following its BGI/ADNOC transaction announcement during 1H.

Following Iran/Israel de- escalation, Brent traded at \(\) 65 - 70/bbl\(with heightened US/Russia sanctions scenarios in focus. 2Q reporting generally met moderate expectations and, as we anticipated, saw the majors sit tight on cash return/ buybacks amid two - way O&G macro. This left YTD SXEP performance broadly aligned with the market despite 2025 EPS revisions undershooting at - 5%. Recurrent media reports of Shell/BP M&A saw Shell issue a definitive denial statement late June, but the repeat nature of reports is likely to sharpen investor focus on the sector - wide role of M&A within through - cycle capital allocation.

- Sector view: We stay tactically cautious into the autumn due to speculation on higher taxes in selected countries (France, Italy) around discussions on 2026 Budgets and in a context where a potential peace deal in the Ukrainian war could bring greater downside pressure to gas (and hence power) prices. We remain positive longer term as we continue to believe in a medium term growth outlook for power demand that should provide support to power prices and returns on new capex.

- SSE (OW, AFL): The second half of 2025 is catalyst rich for SSE, with interim results in November to be soon followed by the results of the UK's next Offshore Wind Auction, AR7, and Final Determinations in UK Electricity Networks, both underpinning value accretive growth. How SSE will fund this is still unknown - we expect an answer in 1Q26 but believe balance sheet concerns are overdone.

- RWE (OW): While near term the stock could be weak due to potential downside in commodity prices, we would see this as a buying opportunity, as we expect the end of 2025 to offer positive catalysts, with a likely positive outcome from AR7 in the UK and the capacity auction for new CCGTs (and batteries) in Germany.

- Orsted (N): We expect Orsted to be a focus for investors given the DKK60bn rights issue to be launched in September, as well as the ongoing "stop work" order on the company's Revolution Wind project in the US. We see the shares as fairly valued given execution risks still remain, although a resumption of US projects could be a positive catalyst in the near term.

- Iberdrola Capital Markets Day: (24 Sep): We expect more details on how and where Iberdrola plans to deploy the up to 15bn of annual capex for which it raised 5bn of equity in July. We expect attention to focus on: US network RoEs, target earnings growth with US$ weakness and Spanish power price declines and M&A.

- EDp Capital Markets Day: (6 Nov): We expect renewables capex to remain moderate (1.5-2GW gross annual additions and asset rotations) and a gradual increase in Iberian networks earnings and capex to keep leverage under control.

- EDp Capital Markets Day: (6 Nov): We expect renewables capex to remain moderate (1.5-2GW gross annual additions and asset rotations) and a gradual increase in Iberian networks earnings and capex to keep leverage under control.

- UK RIIO-T3 Final Determination: (w/c 01 Dec): Final decision for regulatory parameters for UK Electricity Transmission Networks for the 5 year period starting 01 April 2026. We expect a positive outcome, supportive of SSE and National Grid.

- UK AR7 Offshore Wind Auction: (10 Dec): Awarding of subsidies for offshore wind in the UK. We expect offshore wind developers to be disciplined and see this auction as being a positive catalyst for RWE and SSE especially.

Utilities were weak throughout the last 2 months, with an undistinguished performance in July in anticipation of less buoyant earnings momentum than in previous quarters. In August, there was clear underperformance due to the combination of a debate on who could be next with raising equity and, most importantly, with investors moving money into sectors that could benefit from a peace deal in the Ukrainian war and that would not suffer a negative impact from a potential decline in gas prices that could follow such a deal.

- Sector view: We remain constructive on the sector, trading at \(8.9x\) PE, \(1.3x\) PNAV for \(15.5\%\) RoTE in 2027E, implying a CoE of \(c11\%\) which we believe should decline to \(10\%\) over time given: 1) more visibility on the earnings outlook with pre-provision profit growth of \(5\%\) CAGR 25-27E for the sector; 2) stronger balance sheets vs. history with asset quality risks concentrated in specific pockets and the ability to absorb \(250+\) bps of loan loss provisions; 3) stronger capital generation with CET1 of \(14.3\%\) \(25 / 26E\) , offering sustainable returns of \(15 - 16\%\) ROTE, and an attractive total yield of \(9\%\) \(25E\) . We also see tariffs as less of an earnings risk compared to other sectors, although our focus has been on the impact on rates which has been limited so far. Our top picks are Barclays, Deutsche Bank, Intesa Sanpaolo, UBS, Société Générale and NatWest (all OW).

- Barclays (OW): We view valuations as attractive at \(6.6x\) PE, \(0.7x\) PTNAV for an Adj ROTE of \(12.4\%\) \(27E\) as one of the cheapest banks in Europe, which does not reflect the improved sustainability of returns across the longer term, in our view.- UBS (OW): We see the Federal Council proposals providing a worse case scenario for the market, but with a very long lead time, leaving upside from any improvement in the final rules. We see upside from valuation of \(1.3x\) P/TBV vs. MS at \(3x\) .- Société Générale (OW): We see further re-rating potential from: a) earnings upgrades with delivery on ROTE targets \((c9 / 10\%\) in \(25 / 26E\) ), b) total yield at \(c10\%\) pa \(25 - 27E\) (vs. sector \(8\%\) ) and, c) lower CoE with the implied \(\sim 16\%\) \(27E\) too high.- HSBC (N): We remain cautious and below consensus on 1) tariff-related headwinds to global trade which we believe are not fully discounted and, 2) persisting HK CRE risks, with our CoR forecasts at \(c50\) bps p.a. and above normalized levels.
- French political risk, with a confidence vote on September \(8^{\text{th}}\) is a short-term headwind to French Banks' Cost of Equity.

- ABN Capital Markets Day (25 Nov): Market expectations have been rising on cost reduction, higher profitability and share buybacks. With CET1 well ahead of \(14\%\) , there should be room to deliver at least on share buybacks (JPMc €800m in 26-27E).

European Banks (SX7P) have remained the top performing sector in Europe over the summer, outperforming the broader European market (SXXP) by \(c12\%\) since 1st July \((c40\%)\) YTD), with SX7P now the \(2^{\text{nd}}\) largest constituent of the Index. Since \(1^{\text{st}}\) July, we have seen a \(c12\%\) PE re- rating from \(8.5x\) to \(9.6x\) (26E), and consensus EPS revisions of \(+3\%\) for \(26 / 27E\) post 2Q results and compares to EPS downgrades across most other sectors ex- Utilities. Forward rates have remained broadly stable across summer, implying average Euribor rates of \(1.9\% /2.1\%\) for \(25 / 26\) with a reduced risk of rates falling towards \(c1\%\) compared to earlier in the year on the escalation of tariffs, while long bond yields have continued to rise (10Y Bunds \(+15\) bps in July- Aug, \(+34\) bps ytd). We saw all Euro- banks pass ECB stress tests (here) while the UK's Motor Finance decision also removed a material overhang for the sector (here). M&A remains a key sector theme, with UCG also dropping its bid on BAMI (here) and increasing its physical stake in CBK (here).

- Sector view: We expect the private markets managers to perform well in H2 25, on the back of improving exit volumes and strong fundraising. Within traditional asset managers, we expect higher margin active flows to remain challenged, and we expect to see continued strength in passive funds, which favors DWS (OW). On the other hand, we expect strong net flows to persist for asset gatherers, with Italian wealth managers well positioned into H2 given attractive valuations and structural growth trends in the domestic savings market. Lastly, we could see some catch-up on LSEG (OW, AFL) following an undeserved underperformance YTD.

- London Stock Exchange (OW, AFL): We continue to favor the LSEG, and we reiterated our Overweight recommendation (here) after the H1 results. Whilst we understand investors' concerns on the evolving competitive dynamics and the expected headwinds in H2, we also think that the good revenue growth achieved in constant currency, and the progress made with operating leverage (including the revised EBITDA margin guidance) have been overlooked.

- CVC (OW): We see significant upside at CVC, which we upgraded to Overweight in July (here), given an undemanding valuation relative to large cap peers and an improving outlook for transaction activity, which should provide higher conviction on CVC's future carried interest generation. Moreover, we expect the upcoming fundraising of the next Infrastructure vintages (slightly earlier than IPO guidance) to further support sentiment on the shares.

- ICG (OW): We increased our EPS estimates after the recent trading update (see here) to reflect a stronger fundraising pace as well as better deployment in private debt. We expect the fundraising to remain strong over the next few quarters, driven by continued closes in flagship Europe IX as well as the contribution from smaller funds (LP Secondaries, evergreen, real estate debt and equity etc.), while improving sponsor activity could also support a stronger deployment pace in direct lending. At \(\sim 12x\) 2026E P/E, we see significant upside.

- H1 25 results: Partners Group (2nd September), CVC (4th September), Ashmore (5th September), Antin (10th September) and Petershill Partners (25th September)- London Stock Exchange Group Innovation Forum (10 November)- Schroders deep dive on Schroders Capital (Q4 25)- Amundi Medium term Strategic Plan (Q4 25)

H1 25 brought notable beats (for the first time in a while) for the private markets managers, driven by both better carry and stronger fundraising than expectations. Traditional asset managers had more mixed results, with Amundi (N) missing consensus expectations. Asset gatherers printed strong net flows across the board. After a very strong performance YTD for Deutsche Borse (N) and Euronext (N), Q2 results were more muted, while LSEG disappointed on competition concerns. We have raised estimates for most of our coverage, with a few exceptions seeing estimate cuts for Amundi, Deutsche Borse, Man Group (N) and Petershill (OW).

- Sector view: While sector valuations look high relative to history, we remain constructive. The sector offers attractive capital return, supported by strong capitalisation, with a \(\sim 5\%\) 2026E dividend yield (1.4x market) and an additional \(\sim 1\%\) yield from buybacks. The sector has experienced earnings upgrades over 1 and 3-years (well ahead of the market) and has been defensive during recent macro uncertainty, supported by top-line growth in life and P&C and strong investment margins. Our forecasts are ahead of consensus (2026E) for \(\sim 2 / 3\) rds of our coverage.- Beazley (OW): We think the market over-reacted to Beazley's 2Q25 results where it beat consensus earnings but reduced growth guidance. We see concerns on the combined ratio (COR) as overdone, with the potential for management to improve mid-80s COR guidance if low attritional claims experience continues.- Generali (OW): Strong retail motor and non-motor pricing trends in Generali's core continental European markets (e.g. Italy, Spain, Germany) could drive stronger P&C margin expansion than the market expects.- Munich Re (OW): The stock sold off after 1H25 results due to concerns about lowered topline guidance. However, we expect Munich Re to point to a higher ROE target in its upcoming strategic plan, with the potential for materially higher than consensus capital return or capital deployment.- Zurich (UW): Zurich remains one of the most exposed European insurers to the weaker commercial P&C pricing environment and also looks expensive relative to the sector and composite insurer peers. Our operating profit forecasts are \(\sim 3\% - 5\%\) below consensus for 2025E-26E.

- Beazley 3Q25 trading update: (4 Nov): We see the potential for management to improve mid-80s combined ratio guidance.- Generali 3Q25 results: (13 Nov): We see the potential for better-than-consensus margin expansion in P&C.- Munich Re CMD: (11 Dec): We expect Munich Re to present a new strategic plan offering higher ROE targets and better than consensus capital deployment / return.

The majority of stocks have beaten 1H25 consensus expectations thus far, helped by strong investment and underwriting margins. However, the market has reacted negatively to some reductions in topline growth guidance for commercial P&C (re)insurers, e.g. Beazley and Munich Re. In our view, these stocks are taking a more disciplined approach in a softer pricing environment. Life names have generally performed better with CSM growth and investment margins supported by higher than anticipated bond yields.

- Sector view: Poised for a rebound: An uncertain macro outlook and shifting rate environment have seen the German residential names underperform, as well as limiting occupier activity in key subsectors, such as industrials. Looking ahead, we see the listed sector poised to rebound from deeply discounted levels, should the top-down turn more benign, allowing for a further recovery in transaction activity and a re-engagement with fundamentals, which remain broadly robust across the sector. Risks remain, with political events such as the UK Budget and the recently announced confidence vote in France of particular note into H2.

- SEGRO (OW, AFL): We see SEGRO as well positioned for the turn in development activity and sentiment towards industrial real estate in 2H. The group reported an operationally robust 1H in July, where the company secured a \(55\%\) uplift on UK rent reviews and renewals. This positive news was mitigated somewhat by the cut to development capex guidance for 2025, although this doesn't prevent base case seeing \(6\%\) EPS growth this year. As we said in our 1H25 Wrap Up - here - we find it notable that earnings are set to grow by MSD% this year, at a time when the ability to deploy capital into development is perhaps at a cyclical low.

- Great Portland Estates (OW): The London office market continues to move towards the specialists with recovering offices values, more transactions and occupier demand exceeding long term averages. The latter is set to face off against a very limited supply of new office product - a factor we explored in a recent note - here. GPE is well positioned for this recovery with a West End focused office portfolio laden with development potential.

Results season has been in full swing over the summer and generally results have been positive. Several of our covered companies upgraded their earnings guidance (including Vonovia, Klepierre, URW, Merlin) while there was further evidence to suggest that underlying values continue to recover. Listed property performance, though, has been more mixed as the market interprets how the economic and interest rate outlook impact the sector.

- Sector view: We expect updates on US Section 232 tariffs in the coming weeks, where we see a broadly manageable impact for EU Pharma, in part due to the significant US investments announced and the announced 15% cap on the EU. On MFN drug pricing, where an update is anticipated by Sep 29, we continue to see the pathway to implementation as likely to be challenging (see our latest take here).

- AZN (OW): We expect Astra's positive earnings momentum to continue for the remainder of 2025 which, together with incremental pipeline updates, including most notably the BaxHTN Phase III detailed data for baxdrostat at ESC on Aug 31st as well as the DB05 trial for Enhertu vs. Kadyclya in the Adjuvant setting in 4Q 2025, should continue to increase confidence in the achievability of AZN's \(\) 80bn\$ Revenue target by 2030. This is c. 4% ahead of Pre Q2 Company Consensus.

- Novo Nordisk (OW): We expect performance of Novo in 2H 2025 to be driven by a return to growth in US prescriptions as well as delivery of growth in International Operations, where we expect current trends to underpin double-digit (JPMc: 11% CER) Sales growth in 2025 followed by HSD Sales growth in 2026, with delivery of this growth outlook expected to gradually restore confidence in Novo's execution.

- Sanofi (OW): We see current levels offering an attractive entry point for a strong earnings growth story, with a 2025-30 Core EPS CAGR of 6.5%, 2pp ahead of the sector, despite which the shares trade at a 15% discount to the sector on c. 10x 2026 P/E. On the pipeline, we see the upcoming readouts in 2H 2025 offering a more favourable catalyst path than 1H 2025, which saw mixed readouts, with Amiltelimab Atopic Dermatitis COAST-1 trial and the tolobrutinib PERSEUS trial in PPMS both likely to de-risk assets with blockbuster sales potential.

- AZN 2H 2025: Phase III BaxHTN baxdrostat data at ESC on Aug 31, 25 followed by DB05 data for Enhertu & ALXN1850 data in 4Q 2025.- Sanofi 3Q 2025: Phase III amiltelimab COAST-1 readout in AD (preview here).- GSK Blenrep FDA decision on October 23, 2025 following the negative Advisory Committee vote (our take here).- Novo Nordisk 4Q 2025: Phase II amycretin data for the daily oral and weekly subcutaneous formulations in Type II diabetes.- Roche 4Q 2025: giredestrant Phase III persevERA data in 1L mBC + fenebrutinib Phase III FENtrepd data in PPMS.- Bayer 4Q 2025: Asundexian Phase III OCEANIC Stroke data in 4Q 2025 and Supreme Court response on glyphosate.- UCB 3Q/4Q 2025: Atopic Dermatitis Phase I data for galvomikig at EADV followed by Phase II data for donzakimig in 4Q 2025.

3Q'25TD, the EU Large Cap Pharma sector is up \(+0.3\%\) underperforming MSCI Europe \((+2.2\%)\) , largely driven by Novo's profit warning, with AZN outperforming due to positive earnings momentum and pipeline execution.

- Sector view: We see relatively limited opportunities as uncertainties persist and the sector has rebounded since April (Liberation Day). Pockets of opportunity may appear as six of our companies host CMDs in H2 and as the market starts to look into FY26, though this will largely depend on Management teams' ability to manage expectations during Q3 reporting.

- Smith & Nephew (OW, +CW): FY guidance was reiterated despite the H1 beat. With improving sales momentum (Q1 +3.1%, Q2+6.7%, H1 5.0%) and an easy Q3 comp as China VBP headwinds annualise, there could be an argument for raising the FY25 c5% guidance. With a CMD scheduled for early December, we anticipate focus will shift to where the balance of risk on margins lies beyond FY25 - which is the reason we placed the company on Positive Catalyst Watch here.

- Fresenius SE (OW, AFL): At Q2, FY25 revenue guidance was upgraded (to 5-7%) but EBIT guide was reiterated (for 3-7% CER growth). We see scope for Biopharma margin expansion, cost savings coming through in H2 and German federal funding for hospitals that could drive the company to at least the upper end of the margin guide. Details here.

- Carl Zeiss (UW): At Q3 results, Management implied that the lower end of FY25 EBITA guidance is likely and pointed to market and macro headwinds in FY26. FY26 consensus is looking for EBITA of €316m (from c.€250m in FY25) and a 140bps margin expansion from y/y, which looks too optimistic to us, given the headwinds laid out above and off a lowered FY25 base. See details here.

- Diasorin (UW): We see structural challenges at Diasorin from its high exposure to immunodiagnostics, where we see headwinds from increasing competition and reimbursement pressures, and limited scope for margin progression. As a result, we are 7%/12% below consensus FY26/27E EBITDA and see further downside risks to earnings as well as valuation. Initiation here.

Q2 was another volatile quarter for Medtech with earnings surprises more skewed to the downside than upside. Outperforms were generally helped by stock- specific dynamics/ positioning (notably S&N, Philips, SHL, Convatec). Underperformers were subject to macro and market headwinds, notably: Hearing Aids (Amplifon, Demant), Ophthalmology (Carl Zeiss and Alcon) and Dentals (Straumann). Given macro (FX, tariff) headwinds and market uncertainties, we do not view the sector as attractive at current multiples, and remain on the sidelines.

- Sector view: We are incrementally more bullish on the H2 outlook for much of our European coverage, reflecting clear signs of sequential acceleration in European PMIs and resi indicators (albeit from low levels), and following a better-than-expected Q2 reporting season. Electrification remains the key area of strength, with strong demand across the electricity value chain, and short-cycle appears to have bottomed with indications it is turning a corner. While other verticals offer a more mixed picture, we see signs of sequential improvement across the board as we look ahead into the catalyst rich (9 CMD's) H2 and 2026.

- Siemens (OW, AFL): Siemens will address the remaining conglomerate overhang of the Siemens Healthineers holding (currently €73% of €40bn) at the CMD on December 9, prior to which the value of SHL is depressed within the SOTP. The Remain-Co looks set to outperform on earnings growth and/or warrant a premium valuation versus peers thereafter. Net net, we see the risk reward of owning the shares into the CMD as highly favorable on a 6-12 month view.

- Vestas (OW): We like Vestas into H2, driven by the prospect of a rebound in orders and improving visibility on growth in the coming years. We believe the downgrade cycle for the stock is over and the valuation looks attractive in a historical context.

- Metso (OW) remains our key pick amongst the Mining OEMs for three reasons: 1) CMD on Oct 2 will be an important catalyst for the investment case. Importantly, we expect further colour on the Minerals bridge to 20% margins. 2) Further upside to Minerals OE orders given strength of demand. 3) Valuation looks attractive relative to peers (at 11.1x 2026E EV/EBITA versus Mining OEM average at 13.3x).

- IMI (OW) remains a top pick in UK Capital Goods as we continue to see the shares as undervalued, especially as the company continues to build its track record and prove its resilience supported by its PA order book and with upside risk to forecasts supported by IA and Life Sciences.

- CMDs/Investor Days: Metso (2 Oct), SKF (11 Nov), ABB (18 Nov), Assa Abloy (19 Nov), Siemens Energy (19/20 Nov), Alfa Laval (24 Nov), Atlas Copco (26 Nov), Weir (Spotlight on digital and software strategy; 3 Dec) and Siemens (9 Dec).

The sector as a whole beat on orders (c5% on average) more so than it did on sales (B2B of 1.11x), implying better than expected underlying demand. On average, the sector moved \(\sim 10\%\) higher over the period on \(\sim 1\%\) EPS cuts. Of course, performance varies materially from one vertical to the next, with the electricals side of our coverage still shining: Siemens Energy upgraded guidance, Nexans and Prysmian delivered better margins and even Legrand went so far as to nudge medium- term organic growth guidance higher. On the distribution side, Rexel and Wesco results were similarly encouraging. Although other verticals offered a more mixed picture, we see signs of sequential improvement; warehouse automation demand looks solid, mining orders we would describe as good in general, process industry commentary was positive, and whilst still in slightly negative territory, underlying general demand is showing signs of turning a corner.

- Sector view: We remain very positive on the outlook for both the European Civil Aero (ECA) and European Defence Sector (EDS). ECA should enjoy many more years of good growth (OE and aftermarket) even as it continues to grapple with supply chain issues. The main uncertainty is the outlook for the US\$; a weaker US\$ would be a headwind for the ECA sector. We see the pullback in the EDS as a very strong entry point. It is difficult to know if there will be a ceasefire / peace deal between Russia and Ukraine in 2025, but the odds appear rather low in our view. Regardless, we believe that European defence spending is set for strong multi-year growth due to three major drivers: the need to rebuild capability after the c30 year peace dividend; the threat from Russia; and the fact that the US is no longer willing to pay for Europe's defence.

- German Defence stocks: Rheinmetall / Hensoldt / RENK (all OW) were hit the hardest by the potential for a Russia-Ukraine ceasefire, despite the evidence indicating (link) that Germany is fully committed to a major build up of its military capabilities in the next 5-10 years. We expect these three companies to deliver exceptional sales growth, margin expansion, and cash flows in the next five years at least. We see average upside of c30-40-%- in the next 16 months.

- Babcock (OW): BAB is one of the few European defence companies that still looks very undervalued, with the company poised to benefit from both higher UK and international defence spending, and the renaissance in the UK civil nuclear industry. Our analysis suggests that management guidance for sales and margins is conservative.

- Rolls-Royce (OW): RR is a compelling investment in our view, offering a combination of strong markets (civil aero; data centres; German defence; civil nuclear renaissance) and a tremendous amount of ongoing self-help / transformation.
- Babcock - Capital Markets Day (25th Sep)- Hensoldt - Capital Markets Day (11th Nov)- Rheinmetall - Capital Markets Day (18th Nov)- RENK - Capital Markets Day (20th Nov)

Over the last three months the European Civil Aero sector has rallied c15%, whilst the European Defence sector has fallen c10%. This partly reflects a broadening out of the market, with investors taking some profits in EDS and moving into more cyclical sectors. The ECA sector also benefitted from several companies delivering a "beat and raise" with their H1 25 results (Rolls- Royce / Safran / MTU Aero). The EDS sector fell further when Trump initiated his summits with Putin and then with Zelensky and European leaders (link).

- Sector view: Crucial for Europe's automotive sector, the US-EU trade deal in late July imposed a 15% import tariff on most EU goods, including automotive. The 15% tariff, which is a manageable y/y increase of 12.5%, can be mitigated by: a) increased product localization in the US, b) low-single-digit price hikes, and c) the possibility for company-level exemptions, which could take the form of investment exovert credit. We are cautiously optimistic for 2H, as our major concerns—high tariffs, recession risks, CO2 targets in Europe, and Chinese OEMs gaining market share—are now more manageable or less significant, though Chinese OEMs will eventually accelerate as they localize production in Europe.

- Truck stocks: We have placed Volvo (OW) on Positive Catalyst Watch and Triton (N) on Negative Catalyst Watch ahead of Q3 results in October. We expect Volvo to outperform, benefiting from better capacity utilization and earnings momentum in Europe, lean inventories, new product launches in North America, and a high local US capacity. For Triton, our earnings forecasts are 7% and 9% below consensus (BBG) for 2025 and 2026 respectively due to negative volume effects at Scania, as well as in SA, and FX headwinds pressuring margins."

- BMW (OW): BMW remains committed to achieving a 8-10% operating margin in the medium term. Key strategies include: a) stabilizing the China business model with renewed product momentum and dealer network consolidation, b) enhancing electric vehicle profitability with Gen 6 battery technology, offering 40% cost reduction vs. Gen 5, reaching substantial volumes by 2028, c) reducing Capex and R&D and d) returning cash to shareholders through dividends and share buybacks.
- Hyundai Motor's First US Investor Event – organized by J.P. Morgan: 18th Sep- J.P. Morgan Italy Trip: Brembo and Ferrari CMD: 8th and 9th of October. Italy.

Q2 results season was impacted by the US tariff discussion which largely impacted the OEMs and the suppliers and truck OEMs to a lesser extent. Despite the impact of tariffs, overall earnings and cash generation across premium OEMs were relatively strong in H1. VW (N) delivered broadly in line with expectations but in our view FCF is still largely absorbed by exceptional investments and M&A remains strategically important for the firm's competitiveness. Renault (OW) and STLA (OW) surprised negatively in H1 with respectively weaker than expected LCV volumes and weak production volumes in NA. Into H2: a) we have more certainty on tariffs, which should allow companies to plan to mitigate the impact into 2026; b) Co2 emission hurdles seem more manageable in the short term as OEMs have invested in launching electronic cars; and c) OEMs must stabilize their business models in China, a region that has historically contributed strong earnings.

- Sector view: We remain selective and expect the sector's performance to stay mixed, given the uneven end-market demand across sub-sectors. Structural growth areas like energy transition services, U.S. non-residential construction, and credit data digitalization should remain resilient, with end-market demand and capex trends still intact. In contrast, names that are exposed to more cyclical markets such as RS Group (N) and the staffers (Adecco and Randstad) are likely to remain volatile - hence, we monitor closely the early-cycle data to assess the level of stabilization. That said, across the coverage, we see limited risk to 2H expectations as management teams have kept a prudent tone in their comments for the outlook given macro uncertainties and full year guidances are looking rather undemanding from here. In addition, we see potential for M&A to re-emerge as a key theme in 2H, following a rather quiet period YTD, with interest rate conditions becoming more supportive and management commentaries pointing to an active pipeline.

- Adecco (UW): Temp staffing data show mixed momentum across markets, though there are signs of sequential stabilization, making these trends a key focus for 2H. However, gross profit margin is likely to remain under pressure as most segments (temp, perm, etc) will likely continue to weigh negatively. The slow gross margin recovery and concerns over the Akkodis turnaround, could raise further questions around cash conversion and Adecco's relatively levered balance sheet, thereby overshadowing any top-line trends.

- Key Earnings: Hays 1Q (Jun YE, not covered, 10 Oct) - kicks off the staffing reporting season; Rentokil 3Q (23 Oct) - key to watch out for sustainable signs of improvement in the U.S. pest control business; SPIE 3Q (31 Oct) - key to benchmark FY growth given project phasing and easing comps; Teleperformance 3Q (05 Nov) - a must watch for assessing the longer term growth trajectory.- Industry data: French Prisme staffing (08 Sep): key to watch for 2y stack temp staffing developments, Eurozone and UK Manufacturing PMI (23 Sep): key to watch for cyclical names incl staffers, RS Group and Diploma (Seals).- CMD: Adecco (26 Nov): focus on path to mid-term margin and leverage targets; Bunzl (08 Oct): focus on M&A strategy

1H25 reporting for European Business Services was mixed across sub- sectors, but overall results were broadly in- line with expectations, with most companies reiterating full year guidance while maintaining a prudent tone for 2H. Staffers delivered better- than- feared organic growth, though profitability remained under pressure. The TIC names (SGS, Bureau Veritas, Intertek) saw large FX drags, but have generally met organic growth expectations and outperformed consensus on EBITA. Distributors had a much more varied performance as RS Group faced continued challenges particularly in EMEA, while Diploma saw strong momentum in Controls. Other notable standouts include early signs of a turnaround in Rentokil's U.S. business (shares \(+9\%\) on results) and further challenges in Teleperformance's specialized services segment (- 21% on results).

- Sector view: For Logistics, we expect slowing demand trends into 2H25 given implementation of US tariffs and proposed imminent suspension of all de-minimis exemption rules for RoW to US shipments from August 29th. Both US trade policy changes pose risk to ocean freight, air freight and Express demand into the end of the year. In container shipping, we expect supply to continue outgrowing demand, with rates declining into the year-end and tipping the industry back to EBIT losses from 4Q25 onwards. For Airlines, we are constructive into H2, as fuel prices remain relatively low, supply growth looks manageable, and we see opportunities for pricing growth dependent on the airline and its end markets - eg Ryanair (OW) on weak comps and IAG (OW) given better UK/Spain.

- DSV (OW, AFL): We see DSV off to a good start with the Schenker integration, despite a challenging freight backdrop, where the scope of synergy outperformance is high given several areas management is focusing on (customer attrition, road profitability, air & sea yields and IT system optimisation). This creates an attractive idiosyncratic growth opportunity.

- IAG (OW, AFL): We see room for outperformance vs. the other network carriers and expect a new cash return announcement in November. Transatlantic drivers are the most favourable for IAG with constrained UK-US capacity, volume growth from its end markets, and high premium exposure.

- LHA (UW) CMD: (29 Sep): Lufthansa will host a CMD in Munich, where we expect them to outline restructuring efforts at Lufthansa Mainline, and further colour on structural cost/revenue actions it's taking to improve profitability. We are UW Lufthansa as we see downrise risks to consensus this year on weak RASK combined with persistently high costs.

- IAG Q3 results: (07 Nov): We expect a new buyback announcement and/or dividend increase at the Q3. We sit c5% above Bloomberg EBIT median consensus for 2025E. In our view, Transatlantic pricing could accelerate through the back-end of Q3 given more positive US airline commentary recently.

- Weekly freight rates: The development of container spot rates in the coming six weeks (to end of September) will determine the cadence of EBIT performance in 4Q25 and into 2026 when we expect material EBIT losses.

The biggest surprise in logistics was resilient demand in 1H25 for both air and ocean freight and the short- lived spike in container spot rates driven by the stop- and- start of the US tariff policy on Chinese imports. However, this has translated into an early ocean peak season and a likely muted 4Q25 air freight season given the upcoming changes in de- minimis rules. Airlines have been hit by the volatile macro backdrop and geopolitical instability this summer. The biggest surprise has been the short- haul pricing backdrop looks to be more fragile than the market was expecting, as highlighted by easyJet, Jet2 and Wizz. Some carriers have been impacted by Middle East related disruption, and others due to a competitive UK capacity backdrop.

- Sector view: The key debates into H2 centre on whether the 'green shoots' in Europe translate into improved volumes and earnings, and on whether the US remains in 'wait and see' mode. If uncertainty does recede in the US, the pent-up demand from H1 could prove supportive of volumes. Comparing sub-sectors, we continue to prefer the Heavyside to the Lightside. We see structural tailwinds for Heavyside from decarbonisation and pricing premium green cement products are likely to command, while our outlook for Lightside is less constructive in continuing absence of a volume recovery in Europe.

- Heidelberg (OW, AFL): Heidelberg is our Top Pick within Heavyside as we see the shares as one of the biggest opportunities given improving industry fundamentals and pricing power for the European Cement Industry. Also, many of its pilot CCU/S projects are in collaboration with governments, which are funding major portion of costs and thus returns should be attractive before even considering higher pricing point that can be achieved from a cleaner cement product. Heidelberg also continues to deliver good positive price/cost spread and is undergoing a transformation cos-saving initiative, which would culminate in a yearly result contribution of €500m by the end of 2026.

- Saint-Gobain (OW): The weakness following Q2 sales and H1 results provides a renewed entry point given the overall trajectory remains broadly unchanged, with strong execution on margins. We maintain our view that Saint-Gobain offers the most compelling equity story within our Lightside coverage, given its exposure to European renovation and scope for margin improvement as volumes recover.

- CRH Investor Day: (30 Sep): A deeper dive into the business, particularly activities related to roads and water infrastructure.- Saint-Gobain Capital Markets Day: (06 Oct): Management will present their next multi-year strategy and operational targets.- Sika Capital Markets Day: (07 Oct): Sika will host their annual CMD where they typically highlight a product or business line; we do not expect new financial targets or guidance.

Summer reporting season saw multiple guidance downgrades, particularly on Lightside where Rockwool, Kingspan, Sika and Saint- Gobain delivered profit warnings. While we flagged earnings risk into Sika and Kingspan's results, it was a surprise to see management cut their guidance. On Heavyside, there was one profit warning from Buzzi, driven by FX and weaker demand in the US in recent months. Elsewhere on Heavyside, Heidelberg maintained guidance and Holcim delivered a reassuring print in its first earnings since Amrize's spin-off. Notably, CRH delivered the only upgrade, positively surprising the market with a narrowing of guidance that implied LSD consensus upgrades, despite the company's major US exposure.

- Sector view: We prefer toll roads/contractors to airports at present, noting tailwind to contracting activities from Germany's infrastructure plan and historically greater resilience of toll road traffic during economic downturn. We also note the strategic uncertainty facing ADP (OW) and Aena (N), both will submit proposals for their next regulatory periods in coming months and face directionally higher capex requirements. We acknowledge increased political risk for Eiffage and Vinci into H2 as renewed uncertainties have emerged regarding stability of current government in context of France's 2026 budget negotiations but would see share price weakness as potential entry points in the names.

- Eiffage (OW): Eiffage is best positioned to benefit from the upswing in infrastructure spending in Europe, with increasing presence in Germany through its energy division, and its French toll road assets seeing stronger than expected traffic growth in H1.

- Vinci (OW): Equally to Eiffage, we see continuing valuation support and desirable contracting exposure to increased infrastructure investment in Europe. We also highlight the resilience of its French toll road assets, and its diversified airport portfolio.

- Ferrovial (OW): With improved visibility on Schedule 22 provision, leading to positive earnings revisions on 407-ETR, while US ML continue to show robust performance amidst weaker US economic context, investors will be increasingly more comfortable, noting medium term catalysts such as the potential for inclusion in US equity indices. Longer term, we see Ferrovial's portfolio of fast-growing and long duration assets oriented towards North America as highly attractive.
- Fraport Lima Deep Dive: (08 Sep): Fraport to provide news on Lima Airport, following opening of its new €2bn terminal in June.

- ADP ERA proposal: (2025 end): ADP to publish its proposal for a new ERA, which it hopes will be implemented at the start of 2027, and could entail an agreement on capex and tariffs for the next ten years.
- Aena 2026 Tariffs: (2025 end): Aena has proposed a 6.6% tariff increase for 2026, and in H2 the CNMC will announce whether it has accepted the proposal.

- 407-ETR 2026 tariffs: (November/December): Ferrovial (OW) will announce the 2026 tariff schedule for the 407-ETR. We conservatively model a 6% tariff increase, despite consecutive years of DD tariff increases.

1) Fraport: management commentary at Q2 suggesting increased capex expectations for 2026/27, affecting FCF inflection at equity story; 2) Aena announced a proposed 6.6% tariff increase for 2026; 3) 407-ETR (39% of JPMe Ferrovial equity value) reported stronger traffic, and lower Schedule 22 provision, than anticipated; 4) ADP pre-released, disclosing €150m-€180m of one-off non-cash headwinds to H1 net income; eventual print still missed net income expectations.
