- Sector view: The UK Housebuilders have underperformed YTD, down \(4\%\) (vs. the FTSE 100 up \(14\%\) and the FTSE 250 up \(7\%\) ). This comes in the context of increasing doubts regarding the UK Government's ability to meet its target of building 1.5 million new homes this Parliament. House price data has also been weaker in recent months, leading some third party commentators (Rightmove and Savills) to reduce their forecasts for 2025. In our view, with the sector's P/TNAV of \(0.9x\) almost as low as the trough seen in 2022, these adverse developments have now been fully understood by the market. Furthermore, we see reasons for momentum to improve, noting it takes time for the impact of the planning changes implemented since July 2024 to be seen in starts and completions, in addition to the significant increases in funding for the Affordable Homes Programme announced in June.

- Persimmon (OW): We see significant growth potential for Persimmon. The company's mid-term objectives are to achieve \(20\%\) operating margins and ROCE; our scenario analysis indicates that, should Persimmon achieve these by 2029 (while continuing to grow the business), we could see earnings upside of \(95\%\) when comparing 2029E vs. 2024A. We therefore see an attractive opportunity in the shares, which are down \(6\%\) YTD.

- Bellway (OW): Bellway has been a stronger performer relative to the sector (although still a laggard relative to the wider market), down just \(1\%\) YTD, underpinned by robust results and upgrades to guidance this year. In addition to the company's strong earnings momentum we see further catalysts, noting the update on its capital allocation framework and targets to come in October.

- Taylor Wimpey Investor and Analyst event: (1 Oct): Management will present on how the business is positioned to navigate the next stage of the cycle and how the business is setup for growth beyond 2025. 
- Bellway FY25 Results Announcement: (14 Oct): Bellway will provide, alongside its results, a detailed update on its capital allocation framework and targets. 
- Monetary Policy Committee Meetings: (18 Sep, 6 Nov, 18 Dec): The JPMorgan UK Economics Research team no longer expect to see a rate cut in September, but forecast a cut in November remains on track (link). 
- UK Autumn Budget: (late Oct or early Nov): While it is possible that fiscal support for the sector may be announced, there are potential downside risks given the UK's fiscal pressures and the likelihood of tax increases.

Key events include: 1) Barrat Redrow downgraded FY26 completions guidance to imply broadly flat forecasts, citing a slower than expected rate of improvement in the planning system; 2) Taylor Wimpey reported a £222.2m increase in its cladding fire safety provision, reviving the issue as a concern for investors; 3) Mounting fiscal pressures in the UK have weighed on hopes for Help to Buy in the Autumn Budget; and 4) The BoE delivered a hawkish surprise in August, with the committee only narrowly voting for the expected rate cut and the accompanying statement ceasing to describe inflation risks as "two-sided".

J.P. Morgan European Chemical CEO Series: virtual: Sep to Nov 2025: CEOs of JMAT, Air Liquide, Evonik, K+S, IMCD, Solvay, Syensqo, Azelis, Umicore, Yara, Wacker, Akzo, Croda, Clariant, BASF, and Novonesis confirmed to date
UK Leaders Conference London, 18- 19 Nov

- Sector view: Stay selective against a still tough sector backdrop: The sector is beset by more structural issues - industry oversupply and rising competition from Chinese/Asian peers - than just cyclical demand issues. Hence, our conviction on the timing and magnitude of any material earnings in the near-term remains low. While the anti-involution theme in China (link) could be a potential game changer for the sector, there is no clarity on whether and how it will impact the acute oversupply issue in chemicals in China in the near term. The more likely outcome is a slowdown in future capacity expansions, the benefit of which likely won't be seen until the end of this decade, as our bottom-up supply-demand analysis indicates that a proper market healing from the current oversupply environment is unlikely until 2028 across most commodity chains.

- IMCD (OW, AFL): Despite a soft near-term organic growth outlook, we believe that the mid- to long-term prospects for superior organic earnings growth, bolstered by bolt-on acquisitions, remain intact. Hence, the significant pullback and derating of these shares YTD present an attractive entry point.

- Syensqo (OW, AFL): We see the earnings outlook for 2H25 and 2026 as more supportive due to company-specific factors, with the valuation also cheap relative to the quality of the portfolio and mid-term growth prospects.

- BASF (UW): We see material downside potential to consensus estimates (JPMc 3Q/FY25/FY26 adj EBITDA are 7%/5%/6% below Bloomberg consensus) with valuation also more expensive than most other cyclical chemical stocks in our coverage despite higher than average exposure to structural headwinds, weak FCF which will not cover the dividend in both 2025 and 2026, and a more levered balance sheet compared to the sector, on average.

- DSM-Firmenich (UW): We see downside potential to consensus estimates ex. the animal nutrition & health (ANH) business, which is up for sale, as well as some risk that ANH exit deal may be less favorable compared to market expectations and this, in turn, might also result in some disappointment on the magnitude of the incremental share buybacks. Valuations also remain less compelling.

- Possible 3Q trading updates through Sep, which is a busy month of conferences.- Any further concrete updates on the anti-involution theme in China.- BASF CMD: 2 Oct 2025: We expect the event to be largely educational with updates on progress with the existing mid-term strategy and targets.

Most stocks in the sector have been flat to down over the summer due to further earnings cuts driven by a continued weak near- term earnings outlook as well as incremental FX headwinds. Stocks that are seen to be more levered to the China anti- involution theme, namely, BASF and Wacker, have outperformed. Syensqo has also outperformed as their 2H25 outlook was likely seen to be more supportive.

- Sector view: Into H2, we expect modest downside risks to copper prices driven by unwind of US inventory and slowdown post H1 frontloading. However, we view this as a near-term headwind rather than a structural risk to the copper market and we see this as a buying opportunity for those Copper Miners with long-term compelling fundamentals, including Antofagasta (OW, AFL). Among European Steels, we expect equity price direction in H2 to be determined by the European Commission's expected September revisions to EU steel import quotas and safeguarding. We are OW SSAB, Neutral ArcelorMittal and we have placed Voestalpine (N) on +CW. We stay positive on Gold Miners and are OW AngloGold, Fresnillo & Hochschild.

- Glencore (OW): Following a weak operational performance in H1, we forecast strong H2 with \(\sim 50\%\) higher copper output in H2 and EBITDA \(+25\%\) vs H1. Management indicated they do not intend to de-merge coal assets given the recent consultation with shareholders. Thus, we expect the equity thesis in H2'25 to hinge on a successful upswing in operational performance.

- Antofagasta (OW, AFL): ANTO reiterated its copper output guidance with Q2 results. We estimate Q3/Q4'25 output will need to rise \(\sim 10\%\) vs Q2'24 to reach the lower end of guidance, which is relatively modest compared to H2 in 2023/24. We also expect downside risks to open guidance given the weaker Chilean Peso and strong gold prices vs ANTO assumptions.

- Boliden (UW): We expect weak financial performance to persist into H2'25 given low zinc/copper Treatment charges and weaker grade guidance. Additionally, we expect contributions from the newly acquired Lundin mines to fall short of management expectations. We sit \(-18\%\) vs BBG cons for Q3'25 EBIT.

- Voestalpine (N, +CW): We see EU steel producers, particularly Voestalpine, poised for positive gains in Q3/Q4 due to expected revisions to import quotas by the EC. We also identify a future potential financial catalyst in Railways, where VOE may increase financial disclosure.

- European Commission safeguard update: (30th Sep): By the end of Sept, the EC is due to communicate revised safeguard measures relating to EU steel imports under its Steel and Metals Action Plan, with current quotas due to expire in Jun'26. 
- CMD: Norsk Hydro (27th Nov), Rio Tinto (4th Dec), Gold Fields (12 Nov)

The EU Mining & Steel sector (MSCI EU Mining) has performed relatively in line with the broader European market YTD (MSCI EU), however we note that the sector carries significant latent weakness (- 20% vs broader market +40% since Jan'23). Commodities have been broadly strong in H1'25: iron ore \(\sim \$ 100 / t\) , copper \(\sim \$ 9,450 / t\) , aluminum \(\sim \$ 2,500 / t\) given the backdrop of risks posed by slower global growth from tariff risks.

- Sector view: Looking into H2, we expect the US containerboard market to see some upside risk to pricing from supply side driven tightness, as the mill closures announced earlier in the year are implemented. On the European packaging side, we anticipate that testliner prices will continue to track costs, while FBB prices will come under pressure from over-supply following the start-up of Stora Enso's Oulu mill. For pulp, we expect prices to stay near global cost support for the remainder of 2025 due to excess supply, and our conviction in pulp prices moving materially higher from spot prices is low.

- Smurfit WestRock (OW, AFL): Since Q2 results, SW has declined \(\sim 8\%\) , despite beating both consensus and guidance for the quarter. In our view, there are upside risks to Q3 and FY results from (1) conservative guidance by management (primarily related to pricing which we think was incorrectly not considered in its Q3 guidance), (2) potential kraftliner price increases as the supply side tightens and (3) the potential for further industry-wide capacity closures as the US containerboard market continues to undergo structural improvements. Due to our view that Q3 guidance is conservative, we have placed SW on positive Catalyst Watch into the print on the \(30^{\text{th}}\) of October.

- UPM (OW): Our OW on UPM is driven by an improving supply/demand balance for global pulp over the next 2-3 years. However, 2025 will still be plagued by large quantities of new supply at a time when demand is weak. Pulp prices are at cost support and, as is typical at these levels, producers have begun slowing production. However, we have not seen any material permanent capacity closures and so long as this remains the case, it's difficult to paint a bullish picture for pulp into the back half of 2025. Our view for 2026 and 2027 is more optimistic but we would caution against chasing any pulp price rallies in H2.
- Smurfit WestRock Q3 earnings: (October 2025)

In European packaging, waste paper costs continued to decline after the necessary stocking of waste paper by new linerboard entrants ended. As a result, linerboard prices moved lower to quickly offset any cost relief (in line with expectations). While the European packaging market remains in a holding pattern, we have seen positive signs out of the US. In the last two months, we have seen a further 1mtpa of net capacity closures and these latest closures now mean that supply to 2027 will likely be \(\sim 6\%\) lower than 2024 levels while demand has only softened by around \(2\%\) . In our view, further closures are likely but, even if they do not occur, there is a tangible path to reach operating rates of \(>95\%\) in the next 6- 12 months which will be positive for pricing. In pulp, we saw BHKP prices slightly bounce- off their trough and increase to \(\) 505/t\(from the prior\) \ \(495/t\) , while NBSK pulp prices are now at \(\) 690/t\(, which in our view is at or close to the bottom. These price increases coincided with LatAm producers slowing production to try to balance supply/ demand. In our view, these will not be sufficient to drive pulp prices materially from here for the rest of 2025.

- Sector view: For the Semiconductor names, we have likely passed trough revenue and earnings with Q2 results. Going forward, the set up - with still high consensus expectations for 2026 and elevated inventory across the value chain - leaves us cautious on the pace and trajectory of a recovery on both revenues and margins. The picture is brighter for the Semicap names, with the announced US tariff exemption on Semicap equipment likely to support order intake for the balance of the year.

- ASML (OW): Consensus expectations for 2026 revenue growth have fallen from \(\sim 10\%\) pre-Q2 results to \(3.5\%\) which feels increasingly comfortable given clarity on US tariffs (zero) which had been a blocker to H1 orders, as well as a more sure footed customer base (Intel receiving cornerstone investment from Softbank and possibly US Govt.; Samsung signing Tesla manufacturing deal).

- Nokia (OW): Despite enthusiasm at the beginning of the year, 2025 has been challenging given a combination of currency and historic catch-up (Q1 provision impact). The revised guidance looks to be heavily weighted to Q4. The November CMD may offer new targets but given the execution in 2025, investors are likely to want proof before giving credit.

- Infineon (N): Infineon will be the first device company to guide on 2026, and given inventory through the value chain and current consensus (10.4% reported revenue growth, \(\sim 15\%\) constant currency), we are cautious for the remainder of 2025. There will be a mechanical revenue upgrade on the integration of Marvel's Auto Ethernet business (closed 14 Aug) but expectations for \(\sim 15\%\) underlying growth look at risk.

- Sector view: All merchant servicing companies in our coverage noted a deceleration in volume growth in Q2, though companies pointed to idiosyncratic reasons 
- Adyen (OW) = specific Asian customers and Nexi (N) = large customer termination. We expect the macroeconomy to become more of a feature in H2, where consensus and management largely expect a benign backdrop. The incumbent players continue to face questions around competition and market share loss, although we see Nexi as adapting better to a lower growth future (with more aggressive action on costs). Wise (OW), as a cross-border provider, should be more insulated, and we see more robust growth here driven by sustained market share gains.

- Adyen (OW): Despite the headline miss on volumes and revenues, and the initial reaction to the results (initially down -20% on results day), we came away relatively comfortable in the long-term thesis for Adyen. The company reported +23% volume growth (adjusting for Block termination; +5% reported) indicating continued share gains, and delivered EBITDA margin expansion. For the remainder of the year, we expect delivery on the revised guidance (no acceleration in growth expected in H2, -21%cc), with support from weaker comps, especially in Q4. There should be growing confidence on 2026 given commentary on the number of new account wins year to date. The 11 November investor day is likely to provide an early indication on 2027 (current mid-term guidance period runs to 2026), where current Bloomberg consensus is forecasting 22% revenue growth and continued EBITDA margin expansion - management commentary suggests this could be possible (JPMc +21% revenue growth and +240bps margin expansion in 2027).

- Wise (OW): Wise Q1 volumes and revenues were a little lighter than we and the market anticipated, but we expect that the Q1 update should help consensus better model the shape of the year and in particular the take-rate. Platform partnerships should provide \(\sim 2\) pp of volume growth in FY26 and we expect this to grow to \(\sim 4\) pp in FY28 - further announcements of Platform wins continue to provide upside to estimates and the share price.

- Upcoming results: Worldline, Q3 results (21 October); Adyen, Q3 results (29 October); Nexi, Q3 results (6 November); Wise, H1 results (6 November)- Worldline, Capital Makets Day: 6 November, Paris- Adyen, Investor Day: 11 November, Amsterdam

- Sector view: We continue to see secular drivers in the Software market as organisations continue to demand more mechanisms for further automation. Nearer term, however, we think the debate regarding AI disruption and monetisation will remain very much front of mind for investors, and this could lead to some level of volatility in valuations until a stronger consensus is formed. SAP (OW, AFL) is still our highest conviction call on idiosyncratic factors (migration cycle, AI beneficiary and restructuring). Nemetschek (UW) remains our least preferred name on slowing growth (owing to fading migration benefits and multi-year deal revenue recognition timing), alongside a stretched relative valuation.

- SAP (OW, AFL): SAP remains our highest conviction call in European Software. Underlying trends remain robust despite signs of macro pressure in certain customer verticals. As such, we continue to see the core drivers of an attractive equity story very much intact (migration-led backlog growth; multi-year revenue growth acceleration; AI beneficiary; restructuring benefits; expanding margins; balance sheet optionality).

- Nemetschek (UW): While we think Nemetschek operates in a structurally attractive market, near term we have concerns about slowing growth and elevated valuation. We see downside to the organic growth consensus driven by: i) multi-year deal impact fading within the Design revenue mix, as well as ii) a decelerating migration benefit within the Build division. At the same time, shares have outperformed YTD on increased expectations, and its premium valuation relative to peers is now at levels well above average.

- Earnings: SAP \((22^{\mathrm{nd}}\) Oct), DSY \((23^{\mathrm{rd}}\) Oct), HEXA \((24^{\mathrm{th}}\) Oct), AMS \((7^{\mathrm{th}}\) Nov), SGE \((19^{\mathrm{th}}\) Nov), SCT \((22^{\mathrm{nd}}\) Oct), NEM \((5^{\mathrm{th}}\) Nov) and CCC \((9^{\mathrm{th}}\) Sep).- Other: 1) Announcements on consumption-based/hybrid pricing models across AI software vendors. 2) Federal Reserve and ECB policy outcomes. 3) SAP presenting at competitor conferences \((9^{\mathrm{th}}\) and \(16^{\mathrm{th}}\) Sep).

The European Software & IT Services sector has come under some pressure through recent weeks (sector \(- 5\%\) MTD through August vs SXXP \(+4\%\) ). Valuations have been impacted by concerns around AI, particularly for those companies with seat- based revenue models. Despite this, Q225 earnings did not offer any material datapoints to suggest that this trend is playing out within our covered companies. Instead, SAP continued to report healthy cloud backlog and revenue trends. Sage also reported stable organic growth (although ARR did moderate slightly), while Nemetschek, Temenos and IONOS all increased guidance. Earnings quality was a theme throughout the summer, with Dassault Systemes reporting a YoY decline in its IFRS profits and guiding for lower cash generation. Nemetschek also reported softer FCF conversion due in part to multi- year deals. On the M&A front, Capgemini announced the acquisition of WNS, while SoftwareOne completed its merger with Crayon.

- Sector view: AI, macro & M&A are likely to remain key themes. Stock picking will remain key. Our highest conviction OWs are UMG & RELX, while unloved and underwound European broadcasters could continue to outperform.

- RELX PLC (OW, AFL) has sold off on broader AI concerns. We remain convinced that RELX is an AI winner, that STM, Legal & group growth will continue to accelerate & that this will drive a re-rating. The CEO of LexisNexis will present the legal story at our USIC conference in November.

- UMG (OW, AFL): Investors have been reluctant to look through overhang concerns to streaming 2.0 benefits and faster growth in 2026. Benefits are now only 6 months away and retail price rises help de-risk H2. We expect the shares to be materially higher in 6-9 months.

- WK (N): AI concerns are well founded, in our view - if WK does not deliver on the promised acceleration of growth in H2, it could amplify concerns. After factoring in a higher WACC and lower terminal growth, the share price continues to discount close to \(5\%\) organic growth - suggesting AI concerns are not fully in the price.

- FTA (Free-to-air) TV has been the best performing sub-sector so far this year, despite difficult ad comps & weaker than expected macro, supported by cheap valuations, M&A & increased appetite for domestic European stocks. H2 will benefit from easy comps & a return to strong positive ad growth in Q4. Our preferred TV names are TF1(OW), ITV(OW), MFE (OW) & Pro7(OW).

- UMG (H2): 1) US listing - new investors, increased liquidity, improved shareholder base, higher multiple; 2) DSP retail price rises; 3) a streaming 2.0 step up in per sub minimums before the year end which will underwrite double digit subscription next year; 3) the launch & take up of tiers that will stimulate volume growth and drive higher ARPU; 4) a material valuation discount to Spotify, its quality & growth.

- Vivendi (Nov): If Bollore's appeal to the Supreme court (Nov 25th) is unsuccessful then Bollore will have to make a mandatory offer for Vivendi at its fair value which would imply a significant premium to the current share price.

Over the summer, the JPM Media universe was down \(6\%\) . Generally, larger cap, well owned stocks with US exposure underperformed. The best performing stocks were Springer; Pro7 & Vivendi, helped by M&A hopes. Springer & PUB raised FY guidance, RTL & Pro7 cut FY ad expectations while WPP had a profit warning citing account losses & macro headwinds. RELX delivered on the promise of accelerating growth but its share price was impacted by a broader de-rating of Agencies & Info services on AI concerns. We remain convinced PUB & particularly RELX are AI winners, whereas we see some risks for WK. UMG delivered \(9\%\) subscription growth in H1, but a merchandising miss due to the temporary impact of tariffs tarnished otherwise in-line results. There were some misplaced concerns regarding success driven cash outflows as UMG signed, retained & expanded deals with artists, songwriters, independent labels & rights holders.

- Sector view: While Classifieds remain firmly in focus, we argue for a bottom-up selection process to pick the winners in the space. We prefer, in particular, those names with self-help potential in the form of cost savings and tipping point profitability that drives EBITDA growth over the next few years. Further, potential M&A scenarios in Europe and increasing speculation on asset availability in 2026 are now defining industry trends, with the sector likely to see further takeouts in the areas of Online Classifieds and Food Delivery in H2 and beyond.

- Auto1 (OW): While upgrades have focused on GPU, we see upside to volumes and margins. We upgraded estimates on higher-than-anticipated contribution from financial products and cars sold, scanning 10%/18% ahead of 2026/2027 cons adj. EBITDA. We assume market share in the used car transaction market of 3.7% by 2028 (vs 2.5% in 2024 and LT guidance of 10%) and 5% EBITDA margin by 2028 (vs LT guide of 5-9%). With momentum, operational gearing, and scale benefits, we see significant potential: even with still conservative assumptions of a 6.5% market share and a 6% EBITDA margin, we calculate a blue-sky scenario of €60/share.

- Ocado (OW): Ocado Group's operational performance continues to improve in both the Retail operations and Tech Solutions, while bearish arguments are increasingly losing traction. With largely de-risked new CFC ramp-ups, stringent cost management and the Retail operations emerging as the fastest-growing UK retailer, we anticipate a further re-rating by investors helped by a more manageable balance sheet with no further refinancing requirements in the next three years - dismissing a key concern from investors.

- Scout24 (OW, AFL): While revenue benefits from new products are (now) well understood, we believe the market is missing the next leg of the investment case - margin upside. With new CEO Ralf Weitz taking the reins, we expect - in addition to incremental product - upside on costs: 1) more efficient marketing spend, 2) meaningful headcount optimisation efforts post recent acquisitions, and 3) a focus on 'low hanging' AI benefits.
- Prosus (OW): Analyst and Investor Trip, 2 October- Informa (OW): CMD, 17-18 November- Future (OW): Investor Webinar, 26 September

Informa (OW) outperformed through the summer on another beat & raise (here) as investors reappraise the next chapter of growth, expansion & efficiency through One Informa, while Auto1 (OW) continues to see share price support with strong volumes and healthy profitability improvements coming hand in hand, evidencing a turnaround story gaining further ground (here). Ocado (OW) is a name investors are starting to revisit as the efficiency in its Tech Solutions operations is further improving. On the other end, ATG (OW) underperformed through July/Aug, with investors disappointed by capital re-allocation towards M&A (here) and challenged operations, while CTS (OW) shares saw pressure on the back of challenged H125 (here) as high integration costs dented earnings.

- Sector view: We expect event driven catalysts to remain the key determinant of relative intra-sector share price performances over H2. (1) Regulation: Green shoots of change are already being evidenced by localised deregulation, the Draghi report, several 4-to-3 mobile merger approvals with benign remedies, the new Competition Commissioner reviewing merger rules, and the EU sovereignty agenda gaining importance. (2) Consolidation: We believe French consolidation could materialise before year-end. In the mid-term, we also expect mergers across Germany, the UK, Sweden, Denmark and Italy.

- Orange (OW, AFL): \(+55\%\) YTD but the outlook remains catalyst rich: (1) FibreCo deal approval in mid Q4, (2) French consolidation, with reports suggesting a deal may materialise before year-end (here), (3) Orange taking steps to consolidate MasOrange, (4) Orange's Feb'26 CMD, where we expect guidance of DD adj. EPS and ECFC CAGRs.

- Tele2 (OW): Our preferred Nordic Telco: (1) Multi-year pricing runway as \(15\%\) cheaper than market leader, Telia (N); (2) We expect the balance sheet headroom to be used for shareholder returns leading to a DD dividend yield for several years; and (3) Growing EBITDA ahead of Nordic peers, with JPMc 2024-27 organic EBITDA CAGR \(6.6\%\) (Telenor: \(6.4\%\) , Telia: \(2.9\%\) , Elisa: \(3.2\%\) ).

- BT (OW, AFL): Whilst BT shares \(+50\%\) YTD have broken through the top end of their £1-2 trading range, we highlight numerous catalysts ahead: (1) Mar-26E guide screens prudent, and risks are skewed to the upside; (2) BT's competitors are all financially distressed. Consolidation seems likely; (3) As fibre spend normalises, it should unlock a DD EPS and ECFC CAGR. BT's decade-end ECFC target of £3bn seems prudent (JPMc £3.5bn, bull-case £4.0bn).

- Regulation: (1) SFR debt restructuring completion (1 Oct), (2) EC consultation on merger guidelines (ends 3 Sep), after which it will publish a consultation summary report followed by draft guidelines, (3) EC to publish Digital Networks Act, Relevant Markets Review, and European Electronic Communications Code review (Dec), (4) DG COMP to hire new head to replace Olivier Guerset (H2'25) 
- CMDs: KPN (5 Nov), Telenor (11 Nov), Telefonica (Nov, TBC), TI Enterprise Day (H2, TBC)

Telcos have underperformed H2-to-date \(+2\%\) vs SXXP \(+4\%\) , after a strong H1 \(+15\%\) vs SXXP \(+9\%\) . The H1 outperformance reflected top-down rotation, prompted by President Trump's tariffs, as well as event- driven catalysts. However, a soft performance at DT (27% sector weight) owing to FX (USD) and trading (German BB) has since held the sector back. Summer newsflow included: French consolidation discussions, TEF/DT/Sats comments on Defence, new BT/TI CFOs, TMUS deal approvals (11 Jul), SES/Intelsat merger completed (17 Jul), PROX/OBEL fibre JV MoU (25 Jul), OTE RO sale approved (29 Jul), SFR/BOUY sell tower JV (30 Jul), MasOra/VOD fibre JV deal (5 Aug), Softbank sells DT stake (5 Aug), Tele2 Baltics tower JV (6 Aug), Spanish fibre deregulation (14 Aug).

guided for FY 25 PBT to be in line with company cons for £210m at
the time of the update (JPMe £211m). Focus should therefore be on
current trading and on the FY 26 PBT outlook. We model FY 26 PBT
of £213m, c.4% below company cons for £221m. Our lower profit
forecast is driven by a lower top line assumption - we model FY 26
sales -3.5% yoy vs cons -6%

values.Analyst Commentary:
We expect Group adj. EBITDA margin forecast of 19.1% in H125e
with a 20bps margin increase broadly aligned with FY guide. This
performance should be driven by a margin recovery in Makeup while
Fashion and Fragrances should see some pressure due to higher
A&P phasing in H125
